Item 1. Business..summary:
Here are the key facts from PART I - Item 1. Business section as bullet points:

• Virgin Galactic is an aerospace and space travel company pioneering human-first spaceflight for private individuals, researchers, and government agencies.
• The company was founded on a foundation of 20 years of experience in making human spaceflight repeatable and more accessible.
• Virgin Galactic has embarked on a mission to put humans and research experiments into space and return them safely to Earth at an unprecedented frequency with an industry-leading cost structure.
• The company offers access to space for private individuals, researchers, and government agencies, including flying passengers to space and conducting scientific payloads and researcher flights.
• Virgin Galactic's spaceflight system was developed using proprietary technology and processes and is focused on providing space travel experiences for private astronauts, researcher flights, and professional astronaut training.
• The company has exclusive access to the Gateway to Space facility at Spaceport America in New Mexico, which provides a competitive advantage due to its desert climate and relatively predictable weather conditions.
• In December 2018, Virgin Galactic made history by flying its spaceship, VSS Unity, to space from Mojave, California.
• In May 2021, the company conducted the first flight to space from Spaceport America, resulting in the approval for the expansion of its commercial space transportation operator license.
• In July 2021, Virgin Galactic completed the Unity-22 mission, the first spaceflight with a full crew of four mission specialists in the cabin.

Item 1A. Risk Factors.summary:
Here are the key facts from the PART I - Item 1A. Risk Factors section in bullet points:

• The company has incurred net losses of $346.7 million and $502.3 million for the years ended December 31, 2024 and 2023, respectively.
• The company generated limited revenue from its commercial spaceflight operations, which commenced in June 2023.
• The company expects to incur losses in the future and may not be able to achieve or maintain profitability.
• Operating expenses are expected to increase over the next several years as the company scales its spaceflight operations.
• Failure to increase revenue sufficiently to keep pace with investments and other expenses could prevent the company from achieving or maintaining profitability or positive cash flow.

Item 1C. Cybersecurity.summary:
Here are the key facts from PART I - Item 1C. Cybersecurity section in bullet points:

• SPCE utilizes a risk-based approach to cybersecurity and data privacy.
• The company has developed and implemented an Information Security Governance Program aligned with business objectives.
• The program includes a cybersecurity incident response plan and supporting policies for detecting, assessing, reporting, and responding to incidents.
• Senior leadership is informed about security incidents as they happen, and security incidents are managed through to closure.
• No known cybersecurity threats have materially affected or are reasonably likely to materially affect SPCE's operations, business strategy, results of operations, or financial condition.
• The defensive strategy is carefully managed to prevent threats that could impact the business, using industry standard control frameworks like NIST CSF and ISO 27001/27002.
• The Senior Director of Information Technology has over 15 years of global experience in managing technical and cybersecurity organizations.
• SPCE extends its cybersecurity and data privacy standards to third-party service providers where applicable.
• The Board of Directors considers cybersecurity risk as part of its risk oversight function and delegates oversight to the Audit Committee.

Item 2. Properties.summary:
Here are the key facts extracted from PART I - Item 2. Properties section:

• The company operates primarily at locations in California, New Mexico, and Arizona.
• The Mojave Air and Space Port campus in California has over 200,000 square feet of manufacturing and operations facilities.
• The Spaceport America facility in New Mexico spans over 25 square miles of desert landscape with access to more than 6,000 square miles of protected airspace.
• Virgin Galactic is the anchor tenant at Spaceport America under a 20-year lease that expires in 2028, subject to a five-year extension option.
• The design and engineering center in Tustin, California has approximately 100,000 square feet of office space and serves as both corporate headquarters and administrative functions hub.
• A final assembly facility in Arizona consists of two hangars with an aggregate of approximately 150,000 square feet.

Item 3. Legal Proceedings.summary:
Here are the key facts from PART I - Item 3. Legal Proceedings section in bullet points:

• SPCE is subject to various claims, lawsuits, and other legal and administrative proceedings arising in the ordinary course of business.
• Some of these claims may involve highly complex issues with substantial uncertainties that could result in damages or penalties.
• The company does not consider any currently pending claims individually or in aggregate to be material to its business or likely to result in a material adverse effect on future operating results, financial condition, or cash flows.

Item 5. Market for Registrant’s Common E.summary:
Here are the key facts from PART II - Item 5. Market for Registrant’s Common Equity, Related Stockholder Matters and Issuer Purchases of Equity Securities in bullet points:

• As of February 14, 2025, there were 63 holders of record of SPCE's shares of common stock.
• The actual number of stockholders of SPCE's common stock is greater than the number of record holders.
• SPCE's common stock is traded on the NYSE under the symbol "SPCE".
• There have been no recent sales of unregistered equity securities by SPCE.
• There have been no issuer purchases of equity securities by SPCE.

Item 7. Management’s Discussion and Anal.summary:
Here are the key facts from the Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations section:

• Completed sixth commercial spaceflight, 'Galactic 06', in January 2024, marking the first time all four seats aboard VSS Unity were occupied by private astronauts.
• Completed second spaceflight of 2024 and seventh commercial spaceflight to date, 'Galactic 07', in June 2024, carrying one researcher and three private astronauts.
• Paused Unity spaceflights after 'Galactic 07' flight and expect to commence flying with test flights of new Delta Class spaceships in advance of restarting commercial service in 2026.
• Received notice from the NYSE on May 29, 2024, that we were no longer in compliance with Section 802.01C due to average closing price below $1.00 over a 30 consecutive trading-day period.
• Regained compliance with Section 802.01C after the Reverse Stock Split, which was effected on June 14, 2024.
• Completed new manufacturing facility in Arizona in July 2024, where final assembly of next-generation Delta Class spaceships is scheduled to begin in 2025.
• Estimated recurring cost to make each additional spaceship to be between $50 and $60 million.
